page.title: 05OVER WYRESDALE:SHEEP FARMING
page.content: The importance of sheep farming in this area is reflected in the name given to the church in Over Wyresdale -'the Shepherds' Church'. Practically every farm here keeps sheep as a secondary enterprise to dairy or beef farming. The most popular breeds are 'mules' which predominate on the lower slopes where the land is richer, 'mashams' on the higher pastures and horned sheep which are kept on the fells. Mashams are a cross between Dalesbred and Teeswaters, and mules between blue-faced Leicesters and Swaledales. Both are crossed with terminal sires like Suffolks or Texals to produce fat lambs for market in Lancaster. Lambing starts in February on the lower farms and the first lambs are sold in early April. There is one registered pedigree flock in this area - Suffolks - kept at Knowsley Farm.
